options.text: It manipulates packets by mapping IP addresses between two networks.
It conceals packet contents by establishing end-to-end tunnels.
It distributes user packets through load balancing.
It allows users to browse the Internet anonymously.

questions.explanation: The Tor network allows users to browse the Internet anonymously.

questions.question: How can NAT/PAT complicate network security monitoring if NetFlow is being used?

options.text: It hides internal IP addresses by allowing them to share one or a few outside IP addresses.
It disguises the application initiated by a user by manipulating port numbers.
It changes the source and destination MAC addresses.
It conceals the contents of a packet by encrypting the data payload.

questions.explanation: NAT/PAT maps multiple internal IP addresses with only a single or a few outside IP addresses breaking end-to-end flows. The result makes it difficult to log the inside device that is requesting and receiving the traffic.

questions.question: A cyberanalyst is reviewing an entry-point ACL. What three types of ICMP traffic should be allowed to access an internal network from the internet? (Choose three.)
questions.explanation: ACLs should only permit special types of ICMP messages to enter an internal network. Allowed ICMP traffic includes an ICMP reply, source quench (squelch), and any ICMP unreachable messages.

questions.question: A company decides to purchase a device capable of managing load balancing so that traffic will be distributed between their servers. What could be a potential problem using the new device on the network?

options.text: All links to redundant servers will require encrypted tunneling protocols.
It will cause extra traffic going to a server resource that is not available.
The LBM probe messages may appear as suspicious traffic.
It will require the purchase of more servers so that existing servers are not overwhelmed.
The traffic will require more bandwidth to send to multiple servers.

questions.explanation: LBM devices may send probes to different servers to detect that the servers are operating. These probes can appear to be suspicious traffic.

questions.question: Which Windows log records events related to login attempts and operations related to file or object access?
questions.explanation: On a Windows host, security logs record events related to security, such as login attempts and operations related to file or object management and access.

questions.question: What are two of the 5-tuples? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: The components of a 5-tuple include a source IP address and port number, destination IP address and port number, and the protocol in use.

questions.question: Which Windows tool can be used to review host logs?
questions.explanation: Event Viewer in Windows can be used to review entries in various logs.

questions.question: A NIDS/NIPS has identified a threat. Which type of security data will be generated and sent to a logging device?
questions.explanation: Alert data is generated by IPS or IDS devices in response to traffic that violates a rule or matches the signature of a known security threat.

questions.question: What is a feature of the tcpdump tool?

options.text: It provides real-time reporting and long-term analysis of security events.
It records metadata about packet flows.
It can display packet captures in real time or write them to a file.
It uses agents to submit host logs to centralized management servers.

questions.explanation: The tcpdump command line tool is a packet analyzer that captures detailed packet protocol and content data. It can display packet captures in real time or write them to a file.

questions.question: Which type of security data can be used to describe or predict network behavior?
questions.explanation: Statistical data is created through the analysis of other forms of network data. Conclusions from these analyses can be used to describe or predict network behavior.

questions.question: Which statement describes the tcpdump tool?

options.text: It is used to control multiple TCP-based applications.
It is a command-line packet analyzer.
It accepts and analyzes data captured by Wireshark.
It can be used to analyze network log data in order to describe and predict network behavior.

questions.explanation: The tcpdump command-line tool is a popular packet analyzer. It can display packet captures in real time or write packet captures to a file.

questions.question: Which type of data is used by Cisco Cognitive Intelligence to find malicious activity that has bypassed security controls, or entered through unmonitored channels, and is operating inside an enterprise network?
questions.explanation: Cisco Cognitive Intelligence utilizes statistical data for statistical analysis in order to find malicious activity.

questions.question: Which Windows host log event type describes the successful operation of an application, driver, or service?
questions.explanation: The information event type records an event that describes the successful operation of an application, driver, or service.

questions.question: In a Cisco AVC system, in which module is NBAR2 deployed?
questions.explanation: AVC uses Cisco Next Generation Network-Based Application Recognition (NBAR2) to discover and classify the applications in use on the network.

questions.question: What are two popular SIEM platforms? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: Two SIEM platforms used by organizations are Splunk and Security Onion with ELK.

questions.question: Which statement describes an operational characteristic of NetFlow?

options.text: NetFlow can provide services for user access control.
NetFlow collects basic information about the packet flow, not the flow data itself.
NetFlow flow records can be viewed by the tcpdump tool.
NetFlow captures the entire contents of a packet.

questions.explanation: NetFlow collects metadata, or data about the flow, not the flow data itself. It does not capture the entire contents of a packet.

questions.question: What is the host-based intrusion detection tool that is integrated into Security Onion?
questions.explanation: Integrated into the Security Onion, OSSEC is a host-based intrusion detection system (HIDS) that can conduct file integrity monitoring, local log monitoring, system process monitoring, and rootkit detection.

questions.question: Which tool is included with Security Onion that is used by Snort to automatically download new rules?
questions.explanation: PulledPork is a rule management utility included with Security Onion to automatically download rules for Snort.

questions.question: Which tool included in Security Onion is an interactive dashboard interface to Elasticsearch data?
questions.explanation: Kibana is an interactive dashboard interface to Elasticsearch data. It allows querying of NSM data and provides flexible visualizations of that data.

questions.question: Which NIDS tool uses a signature-based approach and native multithreading for alert detection?
questions.explanation: Suricata is a NIDS tool that uses a signature-based approach. It also uses native multithreading, which allows the distribution of packet stream processing across multiple processor cores.

questions.question: Which tool is a Security Onion integrated host-based intrusion detection system?
questions.explanation: Wazuh is a HIDS that will replace OSSEC in Security Onion. It is a full-featured solution that provides a broad spectrum of endpoint protection mechanisms.

questions.question: What are three analysis tools that are integrated into Security Onion? (Choose three.)
questions.explanation: According to the Security Onion architecture, the analysis tools are Sguil, Kibana, and Wireshark.

questions.question: What function is provided by Snort as part of the Security Onion?

options.text: to generate network intrusion alerts by the use of rules and signatures
to view pcap transcripts generated by intrusion detection tools
to display full-packet captures for analysis
to normalize logs from various NSM data logs so they can be represented, stored, and accessed through a common schema

questions.explanation: Snort is a NIDS integrated into Security Onion. It uses rules and signatures to generate alerts.

questions.question: What classification is used for an alert that correctly identifies that an exploit has occurred?
questions.explanation: A true positive occurs when an IDS and IPS signature is correctly fired and an alarm is generated when offending traffic is detected.

questions.question: Which type of analysis relies on predefined conditions and can analyze applications that only use well-known fixed ports?
questions.explanation: Deterministic analysis uses predefined conditions to analyze applications that conform to specification standards, such as performing a port-based analysis.

questions.question: Which type of analysis relies on different methods to establish the likelihood that a security event has happened or will happen?
questions.explanation: Probabilistic methods use powerful tools to create a probabilistic answer as a result of analyzing applications.

questions.question: Which alert classification indicates that exploits are not being detected by installed security systems?
questions.explanation: A false negative classification indicates that a security system has not detected an actual exploit.

questions.question: Which tool would an analyst use to start a workflow investigation?
questions.explanation: Sguil is a GUI-based application used by security analysts to analyze network security events.

questions.question: Which technique is necessary to ensure a private transfer of data using a VPN?
questions.explanation: Confidential and secure transfers of data with VPNs require data encryption.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Tor?

options.text: to donate processor cycles to distributed computational tasks in a processor sharing P2P network
to allow users to browse the Internet anonymously
to securely connect to a remote network over an unsecure link such as an Internet connection
to inspect incoming traffic and look for any that violates a rule or matches the signature of a known exploit

questions.explanation: Tor is a software platform and network of P2P hosts that allow users to browse the Internet anonymously.

questions.question: Which two technologies are primarily used on peer-to-peer networks? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: Bitcoin (distributed ledger) and BitTorrent (file sharing) are primary P2P technologies.

questions.question: Which protocol is exploited by cybercriminals who create malicious iFrames?
questions.explanation: An iFrame is an HTML element used in web pages (HTTP) that allows loading content from another source.

questions.question: Which method is used by some malware to transfer files from infected hosts to a threat actor host?
questions.explanation: Some malware uses ICMP packets to transfer files via ICMP tunneling.

questions.question: Which type of attack is carried out by threat actors against a network to determine which IP addresses, protocols, and ports are allowed by ACLs?
questions.explanation: Threat actors use reconnaissance attacks involving port scanning to determine allowed IPs, protocols, and ports.

questions.question: Which technique would a threat actor use to disguise traces of an ongoing exploit?

options.text: Create an invisible iFrame on a web page.
Corrupt time information by attacking the NTP infrastructure.
Encapsulate other protocols within DNS to evade security measures.

questions.explanation: Threat actors may attack the NTP infrastructure to corrupt time information used in network logs, disguising the timeline of an exploit.

questions.question: After a security monitoring tool identifies a malware attachment entering the network, what is the benefit of performing a retrospective analysis?

options.text: It can determine which network host was first affected.
It can identify how the malware originally entered the network.
It can calculate the probability of a future incident.
A retrospective analysis can help in tracking the behavior of the malware from the identification point forward.

questions.explanation: Retrospective analysis tracks the behavior of the malware from the point of entry forward.

questions.question: Which two services are provided by the NetFlow tool? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: NetFlow provides services including network traffic accounting, usage-based network billing, and network monitoring.

questions.question: Which Cisco appliance can be used to filter network traffic contents to report and deny traffic based on the web server reputation?
questions.explanation:
The Cisco Web Security Appliance (WSA) acts as a web proxy for an enterprise network. WSA can provide many types of logs related to web traffic security including ACL decision logs, malware scan logs, and web reputation filtering logs.

The Cisco Email Security Appliance (ESA) is a tool to monitor most aspects of email delivery, system functioning, antivirus, antispam operations, and blacklist and whitelist decisions. The Cisco ASA is a firewall appliance.

The Cisco Application Visibility and Control (AVC) system combines multiple technologies to recognize, analyze, and control over 1000 applications.

questions.question: What is a key difference between the data captured by NetFlow and data captured by Wireshark?

options.text: NetFlow collects metadata from a network flow whereas Wireshark captures full data packets.
NetFlow data is analyzed by tcpdump whereas Wireshark data is analyzed by nfdump.
NetFlow provides transaction data whereas Wireshark provides session data.
NetFlow data shows network flow contents whereas Wireshark data shows network flow statistics.

questions.explanation: Wireshark captures full packet contents. NetFlow collects metadata about the flow.

questions.question: A system administrator runs a file scan utility on a Windows PC and notices a file lsass.exe in the Program Files directory. What should the administrator do?

options.text: Uninstall the lsass application because it is a legacy application and no longer required by Windows.
Move it to Program Files (x86) because it is a 32bit application.
Open the Task Manager, right-click on the lsass process and choose End Task.
Delete the file because it is probably malware.

questions.explanation: lsass.exe should run from Windows\System32. If found elsewhere, it is likely malware.

questions.question: Match the Windows host log to the messages contained in it.

pairs.left: events logged by various applications
events related to the operation of drivers, processes, and hardware
information about the installation of software, including Windows updates
events related to logon attempts and operations related to file or object management and access

questions.explanation: Application logs track apps. System logs track hardware/drivers. Setup logs track installations. Security logs track logins/access.

questions.question: How does a web proxy device provide data loss prevention (DLP) for an enterprise?

options.text: by inspecting incoming traffic for potential exploits
by scanning and logging outgoing traffic
by checking the reputation of external web servers

questions.explanation: A web proxy provides DLP by scanning outgoing traffic for sensitive information.

questions.question: Match the network monitoring data type with the description.

pairs.left: contains details of network flows including the 5-tuples, the amount of data transmitted, and the duration of data transmission
generated by IPS or IDS devices when suspicious traffic is detected
used to describe and analyze network flow or performance data
includes device-specific server and host logs

questions.explanation: Session data details flows. Alert data comes from IDS/IPS. Statistical data analyzes performance. Transaction data includes logs.

questions.question: Which type of data is used by Cisco Cognitive Intelligence to find malicious activity that has bypassed security controls, or entered through unmonitored channels, and is operating inside an enterprise network?
questions.explanation: Cisco Cognitive Intelligence uses statistical data analysis to find malicious activity.

questions.question: Match the Snort rule source to the description.

pairs.left: open source rules under BSD license
rules created and maintained by Cisco Talos
older rules created by Sourcefire

questions.explanation: ET = Emerging Threats (open source). VRT = Vulnerability Research Team (Cisco Talos). GPL = General Public License (older Sourcefire).

questions.question: What are the three core functions provided by the Security Onion? (Choose three.)
questions.explanation: Security Onion provides full packet capture, intrusion detection, and alert analysis tools.

questions.question: What are two scenarios where probabilistic security analysis is best suited? (Choose two.)

options.text: when analyzing applications designed to circumvent firewalls
when each event is the inevitable result of antecedent causes
when analyzing events with the assumption that they follow predefined steps
when applications that conform to application/networking standards are analyzed
when random variables create difficulty in knowing with certainty the outcome of any given event

questions.explanation: Probabilistic analysis is best for uncertain events (random variables) and complex scenarios like applications circumventing firewalls.

questions.question: Match the characteristic to the method of security analysis.

pairs.left: random variables create difficulty in knowing the outcome of any given event with certainty
analysis of applications that conform to application/networking standards
precise method that yields the same result every time by relying on predefined conditions
preferred method for analyzing applications designed to circumvent firewalls
each event is the inevitable result of antecedent causes

questions.explanation: Probabilistic handles uncertainty and evasion. Deterministic handles standards and predictable causes.

questions.question: What information is contained in the options section of a Snort rule?
questions.explanation: The rule options section consists of the message text describing the alert and metadata.

questions.question: Which classification indicates that an alert is verified as an actual security incident?
questions.explanation: A True Positive is an alert verified to be an actual security incident.

questions.question: A threat actor has successfully breached the network firewall without being detected by the IDS system. What condition describes the lack of alert?
questions.explanation: A false negative is when a system fails to detect an actual exploit.

questions.question: Refer to the exhibit. Which field in the Sguil event window indicates the number of times an event is detected for the same source and destination IP address?
questions.explanation: The CNT field indicates the count of times an event is detected from the same source/destination.

questions.question: Cybersecurity professionals may have access to sensitive data. What one factor should they understand to help them make informed ethical decisions in relation to this data?
questions.explanation: A cybersecurity specialist needs to understand both the law and the interest of the organization to be able to make right decisions.

questions.question: Match the data governance role to the correct function.

pairs.left: Processes personal data on behalf of the data controller
Determines the purposes and means of personal data processing
Implements the classification and security controls for data
Oversees an organization’s data protection strategy
Ensures compliance with policies and procedures

questions.explanation: Data processor processes on behalf of controller. Data controller determines purpose. Data custodian implements controls. Data protection officer oversees strategy. Data owner ensures compliance.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of IT security governance?

options.text: To make decisions to mitigate risk
To define a set of controls that an organization should implement
To provide a set of policies and procedures to manage sensitive data
To provide oversight to ensure that risks are adequately mitigated

questions.explanation: IT security governance demonstrates accountability and provides oversight to ensure that any risks are adequately mitigated and that security strategies are aligned with business objectives.

questions.question: Which of the following frameworks identifies controls based on the latest information about common cyber attacks and provides benchmarks for various platforms?
questions.explanation: The Center for Internet Security (CIS) developed a set of critical security controls to help organizations improve their cyber defenses.

questions.question: What is the function of the Cloud Security Alliance (CSA)?

options.text: It audits the CIA Triad objectives.
It ensures total compliance with the ISO 27000 standards.
It provides security guidance to any organization that uses cloud computing.
It produces a statement of applicability (SOA) which stipulates control objectives and audit controls to be implemented.

questions.explanation: The Cloud Security Alliance (CSA) provides security guidance to any organization that uses cloud computing or wants to assess the overall security risk of a cloud provider.

questions.question: An organization has experienced several incidents involving employees downloading unauthorized software and using unauthorized websites and personal USB devices. What measures could the organization implement to manage these threats? (Choose three correct answers)

options.text: Run computers from a central server rather than localized hard drives

questions.explanation: Measures include conducting security awareness training, enabling content filtering, and disabling USB ports.

questions.question: What federal act law would an individual be subject to if they knowingly accessed a government computer without permission?
questions.explanation: The Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA) prohibits unauthorized access to computer systems, including government computers.

questions.question: What law protects the privacy of an employee’s personal information from being shared with third parties?
questions.explanation: The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLBA) provides opt-out provisions for individuals regarding information sharing with third parties.

questions.question: What act protects the personal information of students in schools?
questions.explanation: Family Education Records and Privacy Act (FERPA) is a US federal law that governs the access to education records.

questions.question: What do penetration tests and red team exercises achieve?

options.text: They provide a list of malware that has successfully penetrated the firewall.
They provide audit controls for all NetBIOS connections made.
They simulate attacks to gauge the security capabilities of an organization.
They provide audit trails for all TCP connections in place at any given time.

questions.explanation: Penetration tests and red team exercises simulate attacks to gauge the security capabilities of an organization.

questions.question: Which of the following principles is used by the U.S. government in its access control models?
questions.explanation: The U.S. government uses the 'need to know' principle in its access control models, granting access only to necessary information.

questions.question: What describes a feature of credentialed scans?

options.text: They are less invasive than non-credentialed scans.
They do not require usernames and passwords to provide authorized access to a system.
They try to exploit vulnerabilities and may even crash the target.
They return fewer false positives and fewer false negatives.

questions.explanation: Credentialed scans use legitimate authentication to scan a system, reducing false positives and negatives compared to non-credentialed scans.

questions.question: An organization has hired a former hacker to test how well the organization would tolerate a real attack by using malicious techniques. What type of testing is the hacker performing for the organization?
questions.explanation: Penetration testing involves simulating a cyberattack against a computer system to check for exploitable vulnerabilities.

questions.question: What network testing tool is used for password auditing and recovery?
questions.explanation: L0phtCrack is a password auditing and recovery application used to test password strength.

questions.question: The laptop of an attacker is attached to a corporate network. The attacker is examining all of the network traffic that is passing through the network interface card. Which network reconnaissance method does this scenario describe?
questions.explanation: Sniffing involves capturing and inspecting data packets moving across a network.

questions.question: An administrator is troubleshooting NetBIOS name resolution on a Windows PC. What command line utility can be used to do this?
questions.explanation: The nbtstat utility is designed to help troubleshoot NetBIOS name resolution problems.

questions.question: Which approach provides automated tools allowing an organization to collect data about security threats from various sources?
questions.explanation: SOAR (Security Orchestration, Automation, and Response) platforms collect data about security threats and respond to low-level events.

questions.question: A new technician was overheard telling colleagues that a secure network password had been discovered through a search of social media sites. What technique was used to acquire the password?
questions.explanation: Passive reconnaissance involves gathering information about a target without directly interacting with it, such as searching public sites.

questions.question: What network scanning tool has advanced features that allows it to use decoy hosts to mask the source of the scan?
questions.explanation: Nmap offers a 'decoy' option (-D) which makes it appear to the remote host that the host(s) specified as decoys are scanning the target network.

questions.question: How does network scanning help assess operations security?

options.text: It can detect open TCP ports on network systems.
It can detect weak or blank passwords.
It can simulate attacks from malicious sources.

questions.explanation: Network scanning is primarily used to identify available hosts and open ports/services on a network.

questions.question: A new person has joined the security operations team for a manufacturing plant. What is a common scope of responsibility for this person?

options.text: managing redundancy operations for all systems
physical and logical security of all business personnel

questions.explanation: A security operations team is typically responsible for the day-to-day maintenance, monitoring, and defense of the organization's network security.

questions.question: What network security testing tool has the ability to provide details on the source of suspicious network activity?
questions.explanation: SIEM systems collect and analyze log data to identify, monitor, and report on security events, including the source of suspicious activity.

questions.question: Which cybersecurity weapon scans for use of default passwords, missing patches, open ports, misconfigurations, and active IP addresses?
questions.explanation: Vulnerability scanners are designed to assess computers and networks for known weaknesses such as missing patches, default passwords, and misconfigurations.

questions.question: What is the primary function of (ISC2)?

options.text: to maintain a list of common vulnerabilities and exposures (CVE) used by prominent security organizations
to maintain a detailed list of all zero-day attacks
to provide a weekly digest of news articles about computer security
to provide vendor neutral education products and career services

questions.explanation: The International Information System Security Certification Consortium, or (ISC)², is a non-profit organization that specializes in information security education and certifications, such as the CISSP.

questions.question: What is the primary function of SANS?

options.text: to maintain the Internet Storm Center
to maintain the list of common vulnerabilities and exposures (CVE)
to foster cooperation and coordination in information sharing, incident prevention, and rapid reaction
to provide vendor neutral education products and career services

questions.explanation: The SANS Institute is known for providing information security training and security research. It also maintains the Internet Storm Center (ISC), which monitors the level of malicious activity on the Internet.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the Center for Internet Security (CIS)?

options.text: to offer 24x7 cyberthreat warnings and advisories, vulnerability identification, and mitigation and incident responses
to provide a security news portal that aggregates the latest breaking news pertaining to alerts, exploits, and vulnerabilities
to maintain a list of common vulnerabilities and exposures (CVE) used by security organizations
to provide vendor-neutral education products and career services to industry professionals worldwide

questions.explanation: The CIS is a non-profit organization focused on enhancing cybersecurity readiness. Through its Multi-State Information Sharing and Analysis Center (MS-ISAC), it provides 24x7 cyberthreat monitoring and warnings.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the Forum of Incident Response and Security Teams (FIRST)?

options.text: to provide vendor neutral education products and career services to industry professionals worldwide
to provide a security news portal that aggregates the latest breaking news pertaining to alerts, exploits, and vulnerabilities
to enable a variety of computer security incident response teams to collaborate, cooperate, and coordinate information sharing, incident prevention, and rapid reaction strategies
to offer 24x7 cyberthreat warnings and advisories, vulnerability identification, and mitigation and incident response

questions.explanation: FIRST is a global association that brings together incident response teams (CSIRTs) from government, commercial, and educational sectors to foster cooperation and coordination in incident handling.

questions.question: Which service is offered by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) that enables real-time exchange of cyberthreat indicators between the U.S. Federal Government and the private sector?
questions.explanation: Automated Indicator Sharing (AIS) is a DHS capability that enables the real-time exchange of cyber threat indicators between the federal government and the private sector.

questions.question: What does the MITRE Corporation create and maintain?
questions.explanation: The MITRE Corporation maintains the Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) list, which is a dictionary of publicly known cybersecurity vulnerabilities.

questions.question: Which threat intelligence sharing open standard specifies, captures, characterizes, and communicates events and properties of network operations?
questions.explanation: Cyber Observable Expression (CybOX) is a standardized schema for specifying, capturing, characterizing, and communicating events and properties of network operations.

questions.question: What is the primary objective of a threat intelligence platform (TIP)?

options.text: to provide a specification for an application layer protocol that allows the communication of CTI over HTTPS
to provide a security operations platform that integrates and enhances diverse security tools and threat intelligence
to provide a standardized schema for specifying, capturing, characterizing, and communicating events and properties of network operations
to aggregate the data in one place and present it in a comprehensible and usable format

questions.explanation: A Threat Intelligence Platform (TIP) is designed to aggregate threat intelligence data from multiple sources in one place and present it in a format that is usable for security analysis.

questions.question: How does FireEye detect and prevent zero-day attacks?

options.text: by keeping a detailed analysis of all viruses and malware
by establishing an authentication parameter prior to any data exchange
by only accepting encrypted data packets that validate against their configured hash values
by addressing all stages of an attack lifecycle with a signature-less engine utilizing stateful attack analysis

questions.explanation: FireEye uses a signature-less Multi-Vector Virtual Execution (MVX) engine that analyzes the state of attacks and addresses all stages of the attack lifecycle to detect zero-day threats.

questions.question: Which service is provided by the Cisco Talos Group?

options.text: preventing online malware from affecting end user devices
collecting information about active, existing, and emerging threats
preventing viruses from affecting end user devices

questions.explanation: Cisco Talos is a threat intelligence group that collects and analyzes information about active, existing, and emerging threats to protect Cisco customers.

questions.question: In profiling a server, what defines what an application is allowed to do or run on a server?
questions.explanation: The service accounts element of a server profile defines the type of service that an application is allowed to run on a given host.

questions.question: In network security assessments, which type of test is used to evaluate the risk posed by vulnerabilities to a specific organization including assessment of the likelihood of attacks and the impact of successful exploits on the organization?
questions.explanation: In risk analysis, security analysts evaluate the risk posed by vulnerabilities, including assessing the likelihood of attacks and the impact of successful exploits.

questions.question: When a network baseline is being established for an organization, which network profile element indicates the time between the establishment of a data flow and its termination?
questions.explanation: Session duration is the time between the establishment of a data flow and its termination.

questions.question: Match the server profile element to the description.

pairs.left: the parameters defining user access and behavior
the TCP and UDP daemons and ports that are allowed to be open on the server
the tasks, processes, and applications that are permitted to run on the server
the definitions of the type of service that an application is allowed to run on a given host

questions.explanation: User accounts define access/behavior. Listening ports define open ports. Software environment defines permitted apps. Service accounts define service permissions.

questions.question: Which type of evaluation includes the assessment of the likelihood of an attack, the type of threat actor likely to perpetrate such an attack, and what the consequences could be to the organization if the exploit is successful?
questions.explanation: Risk analysis involves assessing the likelihood of an attack, potential threat actors, and the consequences of a successful exploit.

questions.question: A cybersecurity analyst is performing a CVSS assessment on an attack where a web link was sent to several employees. Once clicked, an internal attack was launched. Which CVSS Base Metric Group Exploitability metric is used to document that the user had to click on the link in order for the attack to occur?
questions.explanation: The user interaction metric expresses the presence or absence of the requirement for user interaction in order for an exploit to be successful.

questions.question: Which metric class in the CVSS Basic Metric Group identifies the impacts on confidentiality, integrity, and availability?
questions.explanation: The Impact metrics class in the CVSS Base Metric Group identifies the impacts on confidentiality, integrity, and availability.

questions.question: Which metric in the CVSS Base Metric Group is used with an attack vector?

options.text: the proximity of the threat actor to the vulnerability
the determination whether the initial authority changes to a second authority during the exploit
the presence or absence of the requirement for user interaction in order for an exploit to be successful
the number of components, software, hardware, or networks, that are beyond the control of the attacker and that must be present in order for a vulnerability to be successfully exploited

questions.explanation: The attack vector metric reflects how close the threat actor is to the vulnerable component (network, adjacent, local, physical).

questions.question: Which statement describes the threat-vulnerability (T-V) pairing?

options.text: It is the advisory notice from a vulnerability research center.
It is the comparison between known malware and system risks.
It is the detection of malware against a central vulnerability research center.
It is the identification of threats and vulnerabilities and the matching of threats with vulnerabilities.

questions.explanation: Threat-vulnerability (T-V) pairing is the process of identifying threats and vulnerabilities and matching specific threats with specific vulnerabilities.

questions.question: In addressing an identified risk, which strategy aims to shift some of the risk to other parties?
questions.explanation: Risk sharing involves shifting some of the risk to other parties, such as through insurance or outsourcing.

questions.question: Which step in the Vulnerability Management Life Cycle categorizes assets into groups or business units, and assigns a business value to asset groups based on their criticality to business operations?
questions.explanation: The 'prioritize assets' step categorizes assets and assigns business value based on criticality to operations.

questions.question: What is an action that should be taken in the discovery step of the vulnerability management life cycle?
questions.explanation: During the discovery step, an inventory of assets is made, a network baseline is developed, and vulnerabilities are identified.

questions.question: A warning banner that lists the negative outcomes of breaking company policy is displayed each time a computer user logs in to the machine. What type of access control is implemented?
questions.explanation: Deterrent controls, such as warning banners, are designed to discourage individuals from violating security policies by warning them of the consequences.

questions.question: Which two types of controls are effective after a violation of a security policy occurs? (Choose two.)
questions.explanation: Corrective controls attempt to mitigate the impact of a violation, while recovery controls attempt to restore the system to its normal state.

questions.question: Which type of security control includes backup and restore operations, as well as fault-tolerant data storage?
questions.explanation: Recovery controls are deployed to repair or restore resources, functions, and capabilities after a violation or failure. Backups are a classic example.

questions.question: Which statement describes a cybersecurity risk?

options.text: It is a weakness in information systems.
It is the damage incurred by an event which causes disruption of network services.
It is the probability of loss due to a threat.
It is a threat which causes loss of assets.

questions.explanation: Risk is typically defined as the probability or likelihood of a threat exploiting a vulnerability resulting in a loss.

questions.question: A public cloud service company provides data storage services to multiple customers. The company decides to purchase an insurance policy to cover the data loss due to natural disasters. Which risk management action level has the service company taken to manage the potential risk?
questions.explanation: Risk transference (or sharing) involves shifting the risk to a third party, such as an insurance company.

questions.question: Based on the risk management process, what should the cybersecurity team do as the next step when a cybersecurity risk is identified?
questions.explanation: In the risk management process, once a risk is identified, the team must assess (analyze and evaluate) it to understand its magnitude before responding.

questions.question: A user is asked to perform a risk analysis of a company. The user asks for the company asset database that contains a list of all equipment. The user uses this information as part of a risk analysis. Which type of risk analysis could be performed?
questions.explanation: Quantitative risk analysis relies on numerical data, such as monetary asset values derived from an equipment database.

questions.question: Which access control should the IT department use to restore a system back to its normal state?
questions.explanation: Corrective controls are designed to react to an incident and restore the system to its normal operational state.

questions.question: The CEO of a company is concerned that if a data breach should occur and customer data is exposed, the company could be sued. The CEO makes the decision to buy insurance for the company. What type of risk mitigation is the CEO implementing?
questions.explanation: Purchasing insurance is the primary method of risk transference, moving the financial burden of the risk to the insurer.

questions.question: What is the first step in the risk management process that helps to reduce the impact of threats and vulnerabilities?
questions.explanation: Framing the risk is the first step in the risk management process. It establishes the context, assumptions, and constraints for managing risk.

questions.question: Which action should be included in a plan element that is part of a computer security incident response capability (CSIRC)?

options.text: Create an organizational structure and definition of roles, responsibilities, and levels of authority.
Prioritize severity ratings of security incidents.
Develop metrics for measuring the incident response capability and its effectiveness.
Detail how incidents should be handled based on the mission and functions of an organization.

questions.explanation: NIST recommends creating policies, plans, and procedures for establishing and maintaining a CSIRC. A purpose of the plan element is to develop metrics for measuring the incident response capability and its effectiveness.

questions.question: Which two actions can help identify an attacking host during a security incident? (Choose two.)

options.text: Develop identifying criteria for all evidence such as serial number, hostname, and IP address.
Log the time and date that the evidence was collected and the incident remediated.
Use an Internet search engine to gain additional information about the attack.
Determine the location of the recovery and storage of all evidence.
Validate the IP address of the threat actor to determine if it is viable.

questions.explanation:
The following actions can help identify an attacking host during a security incident: 
 Use incident databases to research related activity.
 Validate the IP address of the threat actor to determine if it is a viable one.
 Use an Internet search engine to gain additional information about the attack.
 Monitor the communication channels that some threat actors use, such as IRC.

questions.question: Which meta-feature element in the Diamond Model describes tools and information (such as software, black hat knowledge base, username and password) that the adversary uses for the intrusion event?
questions.explanation: The resources element in the Diamond Model is used to describe one or more external resources used by the adversary for the intrusion event. The resources include software, knowledge gained by the adversary, information (e.g., username/passwords), and assets to carry out the attack.

questions.question: Which term is used in the Diamond Model of intrusion to describe a tool that a threat actor uses toward a target system?
questions.explanation:
The Diamond Model of intrusion contains four parts:
 Adversary - the parties responsible for the intrusion
 Capability - a tool or technique that the adversary uses to attack the victim
 Infrastructure - the network path or paths that the adversaries use to establish and maintain command and control over their capabilities
 Victim - the target of the attack

questions.question: The company you work for has asked you to create a broad plan that includes DRP and getting critical systems to another location in case of disaster. What type of plan are you being asked to create?
questions.explanation: A plan that goes beyond an incident response or DRP also allows for succession planning in case of disaster. The broader plan needs to make sure the company can continue to operate in the face of a disaster.

questions.question: After containing an incident that infected user workstations with malware, what are three effective remediation procedures that an organization can take for eradication? (Choose three.)

options.text: Update and patch the operating system and installed software of all hosts.
Change assigned names and passwords for all devices.
Rebuild hosts with installation media if no backups are available.
Disconnect or disable all wired and wireless network adapters until the remediation is complete.
Rebuild DHCP servers using clean installation media.
Use clean and recent backups to recover hosts.

questions.explanation: To recover infected user workstations, use clean and recent backups or rebuild the PCs with installation media if no backups are available or they have been compromised. Also, fully update and patch the operating system and installed software of all hosts. All users are encouraged to change their passwords for the workstation or workstations they use. Rebuilding DHCP servers is needed only if they are affected by the incident.Also not all devices need to change the name and password configuration setting unless they are affected by the incident.

questions.question: What is a MITRE ATT&CK framework?

options.text: documented processes and procedures for digital forensic analysis
guidelines for the collection of digital evidence
a collection of malware exploits and prevention solutions
a knowledge base of threat actor behavior

questions.explanation: The MITRE framework is a global knowledge base of threat actor behavior. It is based on observation and analysis of real-world exploits with the purpose of describing the behavior of the attacker, not the attack itself. It is designed to enable automated information sharing by defining data structures for the exchange of information between its community of users and MITRE.

questions.question: After a threat actor completes a port scan of the public web server of an organization and identifies a potential vulnerability, what is the next phase for the threat actor in order to prepare and launch an attack as defined in the Cyber Kill Chain?
questions.explanation:
The Cyber Kill Chain specifies seven steps (or phases) and sequences that a threat actor must complete to accomplish an attack: 
 Reconnaissance - The threat actor performs research, gathers intelligence, and selects targets.
 Weaponization - The threat actor uses the information from the reconnaissance phase to develop a weapon against specific targeted systems.
 Delivery - The weapon is transmitted to the target using a delivery vector.
 Exploitation - The threat actor uses the weapon delivered to break the vulnerability and gain control of the target.
 Installation - The threat actor establishes a back door into the system to allow for continued access to the target.
 Command and Control (CnC) - The threat actor establishes command and control (CnC) with the target system.
 Action on Objectives - The threat actor is able to take action on the target system, thus achieving the original objective.

questions.question: According to NIST, which step in the digital forensics process involves extracting relevant information from data?
questions.explanation: The Examination step in the NIST digital forensics process involves processing collected data and extracting relevant information.

questions.question: Which statement describes the Cyber Kill Chain?

options.text: It identifies the steps that adversaries must complete to accomplish their goals.
It is a set of metrics designed to create a way to describe security incidents in a structured and repeatable way.
It uses the OSI model to describe cyberattacks at each of the seven layers.
It specifies common TCP/IP protocols used to fight against cyberattacks.

questions.explanation: The Cyber Kill Chain was developed to identify and prevent cyber intrusions by specifying what threat actors must complete to accomplish their goals.

questions.question: A user is asked to create a disaster recovery plan for a company. The user needs to have a few questions answered by management to proceed. Which three questions should the user ask management as part of the process of creating the plan? (Choose three.)

options.text: How long does the process take?
Who is responsible for the process
Can the individual perform the process?
Where does the individual perform the process?

questions.explanation: Disaster recovery plans are made based on the criticality of a service or process. Answers to questions of who, what, where, and why are necessary for a plan to be successful.

questions.question: A threat actor has gained administrative access to a system and achieved the goal of controlling the system for a future DDoS attack by establishing a communication channel with a CnC owned by the threat actor. Which phase in the Cyber Kill Chain model describes the situation?
questions.explanation:
The Cyber Kill Chain specifies seven steps (or phases) and sequences that a threat actor must complete to accomplish an attack: 
 Reconnaissance - The threat actor performs research, gathers intelligence, and selects targets.
 Weaponization - The threat actor uses the information from the reconnaissance phase to develop a weapon against specific targeted systems.
 Delivery - The weapon is transmitted to the target using a delivery vector.
 Exploitation - The threat actor uses the weapon delivered to break the vulnerability and gain control of the target.
 Installation - The threat actor establishes a back door into the system to allow for continued access to the target.
 Command and Control (CnC) - The threat actor establishes command and control (CnC) with the target system.
 Action on Objectives - The threat actor is able to take action on the target system, thus achieving the original objective.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the policy element in a computer security incident response capability of an organization, as recommended by NIST?

options.text: It provides metrics for measuring the incident response capability and effectiveness.
It details how incidents should be handled based on the organizational mission and functions.
It provides a roadmap for maturing the incident response capability.
It defines how the incident response teams will communicate with the rest of the organization and with other organizations.

questions.explanation: NIST recommends creating policies, plans, and procedures for establishing and maintaining a CSIRC. A purpose of the policy element is to detail how incidents should be handled based on the mission and functions of an organization.

questions.question: According to the Cyber Kill Chain model, after a weapon is delivered to a targeted system, what is the next step that a threat actor would take?
questions.explanation: The threat actor uses the weapon delivered to break the vulnerability and gain control of the target (Exploitation).

questions.question: According to NIST, which step in the digital forensics process involves identifying potential sources of forensic data, its acquisition, handling, and storage?
questions.explanation:
NIST describes the digital forensics process as involving the following four steps:
Collection - the identification of potential sources of forensic data and acquisition, handling, and storage of that data.
Examination - assessing and extracting relevant information from the collected data. This may involve decompression or decryption of the data.
Analysis - drawing conclusions from the data. Salient features, such as people, places, times, events, and so on should be documented.
Reporting - preparing and presenting information that resulted from the analysis. Reporting should be impartial and alternative explanations should be offered if appropriate.

questions.question: Match the intrusion event defined in the Diamond Model of intrusion to the description.

pairs.left: the target of the attack
network path used to establish and maintain command and control
a tool or technique used to attack the victim
the parties responsible for the intrusion

questions.explanation: Victim is the target. Infrastructure is the network path. Capability is the tool/technique. Adversary is the responsible party.

questions.question: What is a chain of custody?

options.text: the documentation surrounding the preservation of evidence related to an incident
the disciplinary measures an organization may perform if an incident is caused by an employee
a plan ensuring that each party involved in an incident response understands how to collect evidence
a list of all of the stakeholders that were exploited by an attacker

questions.explanation: A chain of custody refers to the documentation of evidence collected about an incident that is used by authorities during an investigation.

questions.question: In which step of the NIST incident response process does the CSIRT perform an analysis to determine which networks, systems, or applications are affected; who or what originated the incident; and how the incident is occurring?
questions.explanation: In the detection and analysis phase of the NIST incident response process life cycle, the CSIRT should immediately perform an initial analysis to determine the scope of the incident, such as which networks, systems, or applications are affected; who or what originated the incident; and how the incident is occurring.

questions.question: Match the NIST incident response stakeholder with the role.

pairs.left: preserves attack evidence
designs the budget
develops firewall rules
reviews policies for local or federal guideline violations
performs disciplinary measures

questions.explanation: IT support preserves evidence. Management designs budgets. Information Assurance develops rules. Legal reviews policies. HR performs disciplinary measures.

questions.question: Which type of controls restore the system after a disaster or an event?
questions.explanation: Corrective controls restore the system after a disaster or an event.

questions.question: Which task describes threat attribution?

options.text: determining who is responsible for the attack
reporting the incident to the proper authorities

questions.explanation: Threat attribution refers to determining the individual, organization, or nation responsible for a successful intrusion or attack incident.

questions.question: Which type of data would be considered an example of volatile data?
questions.explanation: Volatile data is data stored in memory such as registers, cache, and RAM, which is lost when power is lost.

questions.question: Place the seven steps defined in the Cyber Kill Chain in the correct order.

pairs.left: step 6
step 4
step 1
step 5
step 7
step 2
step 3

questions.explanation: 1: Reconnaissance, 2: Weaponization, 3: Delivery, 4: Exploitation, 5: Installation, 6: Command and Control, 7: Action on Objectives.

questions.question: Keeping data backups offsite is an example of which type of disaster recovery control?
questions.explanation: Backups can be considered preventive (preventing data loss) or corrective (restoring data). In this context, it often aligns with preventive measures to ensure continuity, but technically restores systems (corrective).

questions.question: What is specified in the plan element of the NIST incident response plan?

options.text: organizational structure and the definition of roles, responsibilities, and levels of authority
incident handling based on the mission of the organization
priority and severity ratings of incidents
metrics for measuring the incident response capability and effectiveness

questions.explanation: One component of the plan element is to develop metrics for measuring the incident response capability and its effectiveness.

questions.question: Which NIST-defined incident response stakeholder is responsible for coordinating incident response with other stakeholders and minimizing the damage of an incident?
questions.explanation: Management is responsible for coordinating the incident response with other stakeholders and minimizing the damage of an incident.

questions.question: A cybersecurity analyst has been called to a crime scene that contains several technology items including a computer. Which technique will be used so that the information found on the computer can be used in court?
questions.explanation: An unaltered disk image preserves the original evidence, preventing inadvertent alteration during the discovery phase.

questions.question: A company is applying the NIST.SP800-61 r2 incident handling process to security events. What are two examples of incidents that are in the category of precursor? (Choose two.)

options.text: a newly-discovered vulnerability in Apache web servers
an IDS alert message being sent
log entries that show a response to a port scan
a host that has been verified as infected with malware
multiple failed logins from an unknown source

questions.explanation: Precursors are signs that an incident might occur in the future, such as a new vulnerability or logs showing a port scan response.

questions.question: What is the objective the threat actor in establishing a two-way communication channel between the target system and a CnC infrastructure?

options.text: to steal network bandwidth from the network where the target is located
to send user data stored on the target to the threat actor
to launch a buffer overflow attack
to allow the threat actor to issue commands to the software that is installed on the target

questions.explanation: With the two-way communication channel (Command and Control), the threat actor is able to issue commands to the malware software installed on the target.

questions.question: Which activity is typically performed by a threat actor in the installation phase of the Cyber Kill Chain?

options.text: Open a two-way communication channel to the CnC infrastructure.
Install a web shell on the target web server for persistent access.
Obtain an automated tool to deliver the malware payload.
Harvest email addresses of user accounts.

questions.explanation: In the installation phase, the threat actor establishes a back door (like a web shell) into the system to allow for continued access.

questions.question: Which type of evidence supports an assertion based on previously obtained evidence?
questions.explanation: Corroborating evidence supports a proposition already supported by initial evidence.

questions.question: What will a threat actor do to create a back door on a compromised target according to the Cyber Kill Chain model?

options.text: Obtain an automated tool to deliver the malware payload.
Open a two-way communications channel to the CnC infrastructure.

questions.explanation: Adding services and autorun keys is a way to create a point of persistent access (back door) during the installation phase.

questions.question: What type of exercise interrupts services to verify that all aspects of a business continuity plan are able to respond to a certain type of incident?
questions.explanation: Operational exercises interrupt services to verify that the designed plans are sufficient to respond to the simulated incident.
